anti_patterns: Don't use excessive exclamation points (max 1 per post)
Don't start posts with 'I'm excited to announce...'
Avoid passive voice when discussing accountability

writing_rules.rule: Start with a hook or surprising statement
writing_rules.example: We almost went bankrupt trying to hire too fast.

writing_rules.rule: Include at least one specific number or data point
writing_rules.example: We saw a 47% increase in retention after this change.

writing_rules.rule: End with a question or call to action
writing_rules.example: What's one assumption you've challenged recently?

writing_rules.rule: Use line breaks for readability (no walls of text)
writing_rules.example: Each thought gets its own line.
When I was at my previous company, we tried X and it failed because Y.

example_posts.content:
We almost fired our best engineer.

Here's what happened:

Three months in, she hadn't shipped a single feature.
The team was frustrated.
I was ready to have 'the conversation.'

Then I looked at the data.

She had:
- Fixed 47 bugs others had given up on
- Documented systems no one understood
- Mentored 2 junior devs who are now crushing it

The lesson?

We were measuring the wrong things.

Not everything that matters shows up in sprint velocity.

What metrics are you over-indexing on?
example_posts.notes: High engagement due to contrarian opening and specific details

example_posts.content:
The best hire I ever made had zero industry experience.

She came from hospitality.

Everyone on the team pushed back.
'She doesn't know SaaS.'
'The learning curve will be too steep.'

Three years later, she runs our entire customer success org.

What she brought that we couldn't teach:
- Genuine empathy for customers
- Ability to stay calm under pressure
- Obsession with service quality

Skills can be taught.
Mindset can't.

Who have you overlooked because they didn't check the 'right' boxes?
example_posts.notes: Story-driven, specific details, ends with question
